thread.title_full: Argos lose to Stampeders in ‘home’ game in Hamilton | Toronto Star

author: Curtis Rush
title: Argos lose to Stampeders in ‘home’ game in Hamilton
text:
HAMILTON—This game felt all wrong from the start.
Only an announced crowd of 3,401 hardy CFL fans braved the cold and the wind to watch the Toronto Argonauts host the Calgary Stampeders in another “home” game away from the Rogers Centre.
The atmosphere at Tim Hortons Field was right out high school.
At least there was the curiosity factor in Fort McMurray, Alta., when the Argos and Eskimos drew 4,900 to the season opener.
This was hardly Saturday Night Lights.
More like Saturday Night Lights Out for Toronto, which lost 27-15 in a game that was worse than the score indicated.
This was the second relocated Argo home game with No. 3 coming up Friday against Montreal, again at Tim Hortons Field.
One side of the stands behind the players’ benches was closed off, so there was no emotion to get the players going.
The weirdness continued for the Argos from the opening kickoff. With a brisk, cold wind in their faces, the Argos began playing as if their brains had frozen stiff.
Trevor Harris was a poor imitation of the quarterback that the Argos have come to expect.
First, he threw an ugly interception on the first series into the wind that led to a touchdown. Then in the third quarter, Harris threw another pick with the wind to kill a drive in Calgary’s territory.
This was not all his fault. There was a strange play call by the Argos, who declined going for a field goal on a third and three on the Calgary 25. Harris’s pass was deflected. The Argos were trying to make a game of this and trailed only 17-7 at the time.
Harris was picked off for a third time with a minute left in the game.
This was the eighth straight game Harris has thrown a pick and he has thrown a CFL worst 16 interceptions this season, although he also leads the league with 30 TD passes.
Harris was overthrowing receivers, underthrowing them and throwing behind them. When he did find the mark, the passes were dropped.
Over the past few games, his receivers have been making Harris look good.
Two weeks ago, it was Chad Owens making a circus catch and on Saturday it was Tori Gurley making a sprawling, seven-yard TD catch that was reviewed to see if he had his hands under the ball when he landed.
Harris was so out of sorts that by halftime, with Calgary ahead 17-0, he was seven of 16 for 66 yards. This is a quarterback who went into the game leading the league with a 71.9 completion percentage.
Harris has yet to prove he can be a bad-weather player. Against the wind, he threw the interception. With the wind, he was letting the ball sail on him.
For Friday, the early forecast is for mostly clear skies and a temperature of 11C in Hamilton. That may be the best news yet for Harris and the Argos.
Of course, the Argos may decide that it’s time to give veteran Ricky Ray his first start of the season.
Even if he comes on in a relief role, it would be great timing to see Ray go against Montreal’s Kevin Glenn in a battle of old-time warriors.
